page_analysis.text_content:
Accessory structure daylight plane (sides & rear)

Fig 25 Front elevation showing accessory-structure daylight plane at the side of the lot

8' from average grade
12' max. height of building
Side lot line

Note: For accessory buildings near the rear & side lot lines, a hipped-gable roof is often the best solution for complying with the accessory-structure daylight plane.

Fig 26 Side elevation showing accessory-structure daylight plane at the rear of the lot

8' from average grade
12' max. height of building
Rear lot line

32

visual_elements.description: Front elevation diagram showing an accessory structure with a dashed line representing the daylight plane at the side of the lot. The diagram includes vertical measurements indicating 8 feet from average grade and a maximum building height of 12 feet. The side lot lines are marked on both sides of the structure.

Side elevation diagram showing an accessory structure with a dashed line representing the daylight plane at the rear of the lot. Vertical measurements indicate 8 feet from average grade and a maximum building height of 12 feet. The rear lot line is marked at the right side of the structure.

A square diagram divided into four triangular sections labeled Front, Rear, and Side on respective edges. Arrows indicate directions: one arrow points upward (Front), one points right (Rear), and two arrows point downward and left (Side). This diagram visually represents the orientation of the lot sides and rear relative to the structure.

additional_notes: Page number 32 at bottom left corner
No handwritten annotations or stamps present
Text and diagrams are clear and legible
